title: Alex Jones Show - 2010 Apr 15 TH [sebaygo1]
description:
.
							
The Alex Jones Show
Thursday, 15 April 2010

audio files are divided at half-hour breaks

[sebaygo1]





Scheduled Guests
................

[show description from the Infowars web site]



Alex welcomes back to the show [hour 3] British consultant, policy adviser, writer, columnist, and hereditary peer, Lord Christopher Monckton, who is a vocal critic of the theory of anthropogenic climate change. Lord Monckton is also a critic of the European Union.
 <a href="
http://scienceandpublicpolicy.org/" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://scienceandpublicpolicy.org/</a> <a href="
http://sppiblog.org/" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://sppiblog.org/</a> <a href="
http://scienceandpublicpolicy.org/monckton/" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://scienceandpublicpolicy.org/monckton/</a>



Alex also talks [hour 2] with economist, former nationally syndicated columnist and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Reagan Administration, Paul Craig Roberts. Mr. Roberts recently announced his retirement from journalism. 
 <a href="
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Craig_Roberts" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Craig_Roberts</a> <a href="
http://www.counterpunch.org/roberts03242010.html" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
http://www.counterpunch.org/roberts03242010.html</a> [farewell essay]



Alex also covers the latest news and takes a number of calls.




_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/_/
 
 It is my opinion that in this time it is virtually
 essential to seek information from a variety of sources, 
 to listen to a spectrum of voices in order to better 
 understand the "big picture." A reliance solely upon
 mainstream corporate media for news and info is a 
 prescription for ignorance. I try to share information
 that counters the monotone of mainstream corporate media.
 NOTE: The material here is made available strictly as
 information. Do not assume support or endorsement on my
 part of all contents. 

 Think for yourself!
 To paraphrase the late William Cooper: 
 Read everything, listen to everything, but believe nothing 
 until you've researched it yourself.
